results.title: Ti-Jean in the land of iron
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Leonard Forest and Raymond Garceau
results.brief_description: No challenge, no obstacle is too great for ten-year-old Ti-Jean. As in his other exploits, he proves equal to every situation. Working his boat passage, flying an aircraft, saving a mine from disaster—all are in a day’s work for him before he again mounts his white horse and rides off in search of new adventures.

results.title: Ti-Jean goes west
results.brief_description: The Canadian prairies, seen through the eyes of a ten-year-old boy. Ti-Jean reaches the Golden West and hires out as a harvest hand. he learns to handle the equipment; he learns about the life of prairie farmers and, when a storm threatens, he works with the strength of ten to save a farmer’s crop.

results.title: Ti-Jean goes lumbering [B&W]
results.brief_description: A French-Canadian folk tale about the fantastic exploits of a mysterious little boy who one day rides into a winter logging camp on a big white horse. Ti-Jean’s feats dwarf those of even the hardiest lumberjack as he fells timber, cuts, carries and piles heavy logs and comes out the victor in every contest. The film portrays typical life and work in a Canadian logging camp.

results.title: Thyrotoxicosis: selection of treatment (D)
results.creator_credit: University of Glasgow Television Service and Peter Coltman
results.brief_description: Examines the use of drugs in the treatment of thyrotoxicosis and compares it wit h other forms of therapy. Concludes that the drug therapy is to be preferred bec ause it does the least damage and has the lowest morbidity. This view is supported by diagrammatic explanations. Intended for medical students, hospital physicians and GPs.

results.title: THX 1138
results.creator_credit: American Zoetrope, Lawrence Sturhahn and George Lucas
results.brief_description: A future society of sophisticated technology in a subterranean city. Each individual has a number, not a name. Human responses and inclinations are suppressed by constant surveillance, robot policeman, and a diet of tranquiliser drugs. A couple break the rules, conceive a child and are put in prison where they meet a man who claims to know an escape route. Starring Robert Duvall, Donald Pleasence and Maggie McOmie.

results.title: Thus spake Richard Strauss
results.creator_credit: CBS Telelvision Network and Roger Englander
results.brief_description: Leonard Bernstein narrates and conducts a performance of Richard Strauss’s “Thus spake Zarathustra”, a tone poem, based on the work by the German philosopher, Friedrich Nietzsche. Bernstein discusses the eight sections of the tone poem and shows how their philosophical content is expressed by the musical structure. Features the New York Philharmonic orchestra.

results.title: Thursday's children
results.creator_credit: Morse Films, World Wide, Guy Brenton and Lindsay Anderson
results.brief_description: Academy award winning documentary by Lindsay Anderson and Guy Brenton about the problem of educating children who are born deaf, and stresses the mutual trust and spontaneity of expression that deafness gives these children in compensation. Narrated by Sir Richard Burton, the Royal School for the Deaf in Margate is used to demonstrate how children must first be introduced to the idea of words, understand when words are spoken and to reproduce sounds they cannot hear. A masterpiece of sensitivity and dignity.

results.title: Thundering wheels
results.creator_credit: Nagai Eigasha, Hideo Kamo and Yoshi Tanaka
results.brief_description: A survey of the Japanese National Railways. From small beginnings in 1872, the system has expanded the length and breadth of Japan’s four islands, covering a distance in excess of 13,000 miles.

results.title: Thunderbirds. Volume 3
results.creator_credit: APF Television Production, Associated Television, Gerry Anderson, David Lane, Alan Pattillo and David Elliot
results.brief_description: 1960s British animated television series set in 2065, about a family and their associates combating various dangers with a mix of technology and intelligence. Using marionettes, “Thunderbirds” made impressive use of supermarionation - a puppetry technique that used fine wires and electronics to move the puppets’ lips. John, Virgil, Scott, Gordon and Alan Tracy are brothers who combat danger using their numerous spacecrafts, working for International Rescue, helmed by their father Jeff. Brains, Lady Penelope, Parker, Kyrano and Tin-Tin ably assist the family on their missions. Four episodes from the show are: “The Brink of disaster”: Jeff, Brains and Tin-Tin must think quickly to save themselves and the others onboard, when caught on a perilous monorail journey. “Perils of Penelope”: When Lady Penelope is kidnapped she is set to die unless an eminent scientist reveals his secrets to the enemy. Virgil and Gordon battle to free her. “Terror in New York City”: When the Empire State Building is moved to a new site, several men are trapped in a cave-in. Brains combats the odds and a massive tidal wave. “End of the road”: When a family friend is stranded on a cliff, the Tracy boys band together to rescue him.
